awd_titl_txt: Expansion of the CyberWatch West Resource Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a critical need and a major challenge. To meet this need, business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches.  The growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have the knowledge and skills needed to protect digital infrastructure. In 2018, NSF funded the CyberWatch West Resource Center as an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Resource Center to support cybersecurity education at two-year colleges across the nation (NSF Award DUE-1800589). In 2019, the funding level for new Resource Centers was raised to $1.65 million (NSF 18-571). With this new award, the CyberWatch West Resource Center will be fully funded as an ATE resource center, enabling the Center to expand the scope of its activities. Specifically, the CyberWatch West Resource Center will expand its mentoring efforts to help more colleges build and strengthen their cybersecurity programs.  The Center will also develop additional curricular resources and conduct additional educational activities to inform students about careers in cybersecurity and match them with employers.


The expanded Center will undertake four interrelated efforts that complement and/or expand the previously funded activities:  (1) provide mentoring, technical assistance, and leadership training to educators and prospective grantees who want to implement and improve cybersecurity education programs; (2) convert, consolidate, and disseminate cybersecurity curricula (including modules developed through the Catalyzing Computing and Cybersecurity in Community Colleges project, NSF Award DGE-1548315) in accessible formats that integrate with common online learning management systems; (3) partner with business and industry to provide credit-bearing cybersecurity training modules that meet the needs of current employees in small businesses, fit into college curricula, and are aligned with the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education Framework's work roles; and (4) host virtual career fairs and operate an online job board, which will broadly disseminate employment opportunities and directly connect students with prospective employers.  This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program, which focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Expansion of the CyberWatch West (CWW) Resource Center Outcomes Report 

The CWW Resource Center expansion, rebranded as the National Cybersecurity Training and Educational (NCyTE) Center comprised four major goals and in addition to its existing activities, its expansion through new partnerships and initiatives significantly contributed to both the quantitiy and quaity of the cybersecurity workforce.  

Improved the Current and Future Direction of Cybersecurity Education in the U.S.

NCyTE convened a Future Directions 2022 Summit on June 26-28, 2022.Summit participants shared their opinions in group discussions which resulted in "The Role of Community Colleges in Cybersecurity Education: Future Directions 2022” publication with recommendations and an action plan. NCyTE distributed the publication from the summit through its website and its other resource channels such as the Mall of America event scheduled in August 2022. Hard copies were also distributed to all attendees and made available as appropriate for informing government and other initiatives related to the national workforce shortage. This body of work and publication contributed to the National Cybersecurity Strategy on National Cyber Workforce and Education Strategy published by the Office of the National Cyber Director, Executive Office of the President.  

Cybersecurity Faculty Development Academies and Bootcamps Results 

CWW organized and launched its first faculty development academies and bootcamps. Academies were developed for college faculty from both cyber and non-cyber disciplines to support securing credentials and increasing pedagogical skills in cyber. Academies range from 16 to 32 hours of instruction and include participation stipends for successful completers depending on the length of the academy. Training provisions faculty/participants with tools and resources to incorporate cybersecurity education across disciplines.Effort was made to connect with other ATE centers to customize academies for their disciplines and specific needs. Over 116 faculty professional development offerings were provided, and 1,500 existing and new faculty were trained.   

Faculty Diversity Fellowship Bootcamp Results 

The Faculty Diversity Fellowship Bootcamp was offered virtually starting in April 2022 for students in their last year in a bachelor's or master's degree program in cybersecurity or other STEM discipline, affording them an opportunity to explore a career in teaching. Participants attend a 4-hour orientation, followed by a total of 48-hours of classroom instruction on pedagogy and cybersecurity skills, and then they are paired with a participating community college for a 60-hour teaching assistant assignment.  

One-hundred and seventy-nine (179) students applied to participate, and 96 have started the program, and 28 have graduated. 82% of the participants are female or an underrepresented group.  

Curriculum Update and Expansion Project Results 

NCyTE continues to develop new cyber curricular resources for other disciplines, and for CTE and high school instructors, and is now hosting 33 interactive e-mates either developed with NCyTE funding or other grants hosted at Moraine Valley and Brookdale Community Colleges. 

NCyTE continues to add to its YouTube library of video resources that can be adapted to existing curriculum. NCyTE’s video resources address cyber across multi-disciplinary topics/industry sectors; eight new video modules were added.

All curricular resources are available on the NCyTE Website and/or CLARK.center. NCyTE’s YouTube videos have been viewed  82,420 times and the NCyTE collection on CLARK.Center has had nearly 12,000 interactions.  

C5 Project Lessons Transformation to Learning Management System (LMS) Formats Project Results  

In fall 2021 NCyTE updated the C5 modules that were developed under the C5 grant and transitioned them to the CLARK.Center repository. These modules are now aligned to AP Computer Science Principles and the CAE Knowledge Units to enhance pathways transitions. These resources are being used in various NCyTE CTE, JROTC and faculty development trainings/workshops/academies. 

MOS Pathways Results 

A new MOS document was completed and posted on the NCyTE website to include updates to the course equivalencies. The MOS pathways documents, originally developed under previous NSF grant awards to WCC remains popular as a resource and has been downloaded 749 times from the NCyTE website since it was originally posted. 

 

 Virtual Career Fair Results 

NCyTE partnered with the CAE Community National Center to organize and host an annual virtual career fair (VCF). Most employers who responded to a follow-up survey stated their experience at the VCF convinced him/her that students/alumni from CAE designated institutions can be strong candidates for employment. 

Cumulatively, nearly 5,000 students engaged in the VCFs and other NCyTE sponsored activities. All participants engaged with employers and came away with enhanced awareness of cybersecurity career opportunities, scheduled or call backs for job interviews, and in some cases employment. 

 Impact:   

The project has expanded and diversified the potential cybersecurity employment pipeline through new and innovative approaches and increased multi-stakeholder partnerships and collaboration. 

To address the ever-growing demand for cybersecurity professionals, as a nation we must look beyond traditional models, diversify the workforce and continue to engage and educate youth in new ways. These pilots and projects accomplish that goal. 


Last Modified: 11/19/2024
Modified by: Stephen R Troupe
